stem: A patient with confirmed pulmonary tuberculosis has been on appropriate therapy for three weeks and is clinically improving. When can airborne precautions typically be discontinued?
option_a: After three consecutive negative sputum smears collected per protocol
rationale_correct: Airborne precautions for TB are discontinued after documented clinical improvement and required negative sputum smear results per institutional protocol.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct because objective microbiologic clearance is required. | B-D: Insufficient to ensure noninfectious status.
common_trap: Ending isolation based solely on symptom improvement.
exam_logic: Airborne isolation requires objective clearance criteria.

stem: Which pathogen requires droplet precautions rather than airborne precautions?
rationale_correct: Influenza spreads primarily via droplets and requires droplet precautions.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct droplet transmission. | B-D: Require airborne precautions.
common_trap: Confusing measles or TB with droplet-only organisms.

stem: What is the primary purpose of a negative pressure room?
option_a: Prevent contaminated air from escaping into the hallway
option_b: Protect the patient from outside contaminants
rationale_correct: Negative pressure rooms protect others by containing airborne contaminants within the room.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct containment principle. | B: Positive pressure protects patient. | C-D: Not purpose of isolation rooms.
common_trap: Reversing positive and negative pressure functions.

stem: Which action best reduces needlestick injury risk during line placement?
option_d: Placing used sharps on bedside tray temporarily
rationale_correct: Safety-engineered devices are proven to reduce sharps injuries.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct evidence-based prevention. | B-D: Increase exposure risk.
common_trap: Believing careful recapping is safe practice.
exam_logic: Use engineered controls over behavioral reliance.

stem: Which is one of the WHO Five Moments for Hand Hygiene?
rationale_correct: Hand hygiene is required before patient contact to prevent transmission.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct WHO moment. | B-D: Not part of the five defined moments.
common_trap: Forgetting hand hygiene before patient contact.

stem: Multiple patients on a unit develop the same multidrug-resistant organism. What is the most appropriate immediate action?
option_a: Notify infection prevention and implement cohorting
option_b: Wait for confirmatory cultures on all patients
option_c: Transfer all patients to different units
rationale_correct: Rapid notification and cohorting help limit spread during suspected outbreaks.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct outbreak containment step. | B: Delays intervention. | C: May spread organism. | D: Inappropriate.
common_trap: Waiting for full confirmation before acting.

stem: A patient with a productive cough is being transported for imaging. What infection control measure is most appropriate?
option_a: Place a surgical mask on the patient
rationale_correct: Source control reduces droplet spread during transport.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct source control measure. | B: Does not address source control. | C-D: Inappropriate.
common_trap: Protecting staff but not controlling source.

stem: Which disinfectant property is most important when cleaning surfaces contaminated with C. difficile?
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct spore coverage. | B-D: Cosmetic or secondary factors.
common_trap: Using standard disinfectant for spore organisms.

stem: Standard precautions apply to which patients?
rationale_correct: Standard precautions are universal and apply to all patients.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct universal application. | B-D: Incorrect limited scope.
common_trap: Assuming precautions only apply to known infections.

stem: After a high-risk needle exposure to a patient with known HIV infection, when should post-exposure prophylaxis ideally begin?
option_a: As soon as possible, preferably within hours
option_c: After confirmatory serology in exposed worker
rationale_correct: HIV post-exposure prophylaxis is most effective when started immediately.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct urgent initiation. | B-D: Delay reduces effectiveness.
common_trap: Waiting for symptoms or delayed testing.
